_prev_prog_2.Description: The prevention program in place involves daily inspection of equipment, routine preventative maintenance, and frequent testing of gas detector and alarm systems.  Chlorine cylinders in use are on scales for measurement of chlorine consumption and for inventory purposes.  The building contains chlorine gas detection alarms.  Standard Operating Procedures and Emergency Operations Procedures are in place.  The Greater Hazleton Joint Sewer Authority has delegated emergency response to the local fire department, the West Hazleton Fire Company, and with the County LEPC and HAZMAT Response Teams.  The LEPC Off-Site Emergency Response Plan from SARA III is the de facto emergency response plan for the site.  Incident chain-of-command is listed in this document.  Furthermore, authority employees are trained in chlorine safety for routine operations.  Routine internal compliance auidts are performed on a regular basis.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Greater Hazleton Joint Sewer Authority (GHJSA) owns and operates GHJSA Wastewater Treatment Plant located in Hazleton Township, Luzerne County, Pennsylvania.  The service area includes the City of Hazleton, the Borough of West Hazleton, and portions of Hazle Township.  The wastewater treatment plant, located at Jaycee Drive at Oscar Thomas Drive in the Valmont Industrial Park, has an annual average design flow of 8.92 million gallons per day (mgd).  The WWTP operates under NPDES Permit No. PA 0026921 and discharges treated effluent to the Black Creek.   Wastewater treatment processes include grit and coarse screenings removal, preliminary sedimentation, secondary bio-towers and activated sludge treatment, clarification, and disinfection.  Solids removed from the treatment process are dewatered and disposed in a landfill.  The plant is operated 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

The WWTP includes a Chlorinator Building, which contains three (3) one ton containers of chlorine (liquefied under pressure), four (4) chlorinators, various safety equipment, and instrumentation consisting of flow recorders, electrical panels, and a gas detector/alarm unit.  The chlorinator system extracts chlorine gas from the storage cylinders through high pressure regulators and dissolves this gas into water to form a disinfection solution that is used to kill pathogenic bacteria in treated wastewater prior to its discharge into the creek.  Up to eight (8) one ton cylinders may be stored outside in cradles on a raised pad adjacent to the Chlorinator Building.  Plant operators regularly check the building and its equipment, inventorying the rate of chlorine use and adjusting the rate as necessary.  Accounting for administrative controls on inventory, the maximum intended inventory is 16,000 pounds.  ?Wastewater treatment? is not an industry classification listed in Section 40 CFR 68.10(d), nor are municipal wastewater treatment plants regulated under OSHA PSM in Pennsylvania.
